awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Massive Uncoordinated and Sporadic Multiple Access -- Strengthening Connections between Coding and Random Access
awd_abstract_narration:
The wireless landscape is poised to change, once again, within the next few years due to the emergence of machine-driven communications. This creates new challenges for wireless traffic, with packets originating from sporadic transmissions rather than sustained connections. Currently deployed scheduling policies are ill-equipped to deal with such traffic because they rely on gathering information about channel quality and queue length for every active device. The goal of this research initiative is to address this deficiency and devise novel access schemes tailored to massive uncoordinated and sporadic multiple access, thereby readying wireless infrastructures for the traffic of tomorrow. The broader impacts of this research program include providing pragmatic solutions to some of the challenges posed by an evolving wireless landscape, strengthening wireless infrastructures, and contributing to the training of a globally competitive Science, Technology, Engineering and Math  workforce.  The research tasks are attuned to societal needs in information technologies, an important economic driver for our nation.  The wide dissemination of the findings will enhance the scientific understanding of wireless systems, access strategies, and iterative methods.

The intellectual merit of this research initiative lies in exploiting the close connections between message-passing decoding and serial interference cancellation to create new access strategies. Linking advances in iterative methods to uncoordinated random access embodies the type of crosscutting research that can lead to disruptive technologies and paradigm shifts. This project embraces the evolving perspective of harnessing interference in wireless networks rather than fighting it or avoiding it. This viewpoint underlies many recent successes in network coding and distributed storage. This project brings forth such a perspective in the design of large-scale wireless networks.

por.por_cntn:
With the emergence of machine-driven communications, an important component of the Internet of Things and 5G wireless communications, the nature of wireless traffic is changing. In addition to individual users who interact using personal phones or mobile computers, a sizable portion of wireless resources will be consumed by legions of unattended devices that seek to disseminate information in a random fashion. Currently deployed wireless access schemes are not well-suited for the transmission of short packets of data generated sporadically by a myriad of wireless devices.  The overarching goal of this project was to address this deficiency and devise novel access schemes and coding schemes that permit a massive number of devices to transmit information in an uncoordinated fashion to a base station in the uplink.

 

Important outcomes from this project include several novel encoding and decoding schemes that reduce the transmission power required for a massive number of devices to communicate to a base station in an uncoordinated fashion. This is also termed as power efficiency in the literature. Specifically, (i) we designed a novel framework, called coded compressed sensing, that combines ideas from coding theory and compressed sensing and showed that this framework can be used to design high performance multiple access schemes, (ii) we designed novel coding schemes based on combining codes on graphs, compressed sensing, and sparse interleave division multiplexing and we highlighted the importance of sparsifying transmissions in this context, (iii) we designed new coding schemes based on recent developments in coding theory including polar codes. We continually improved our designs through the period of this grant and our final designs from this project are currently the state of the art in terms of power efficiency for massive uncoordinated multiple access with short packets.  We also showed that coding schemes can be designed even in the presence of asynchronous transmissions between the multiple users.   

Another important outcome from the project is a theory of security for control systems. Specifically, analogous to the classical notions of controllable and unobservable subspaces of a linear dynamical system, we introduced the notions of securable and unsecurable subspace of a linear dynamical system. These subspaces have important operational meaning in the context of both deterministic and stochastic linear systems. For example, an interpretation of the unsecurable subspace in the context of a deterministic system is as the set of states that the malicious nodes can steer the system to ever, without the honest nodes in the system ever detecting that there has been any malicious activity in the system. From a system designer's perspective, these results can be translated in a straightforward manner into constraints that the system parameters should satisfy in order to achieve a specified resilience.

We developed two MAC protocols – TrackMAC and IRIS. TrackMAC a directional medium access control protocol for millimeter-wave local area networks, that allows an access point to efficiently track every station associated with it at small overheads. This protocol can be implemented squarely within the specifications of the IEEE 802.11ad standard for millimeter-wave local area networking. The Iris protocol is designed to distributedly coordinate the nodes so that transmitters and their intended receivers align their antenna boresights to establish a physical link between them when required. We established certain performance guarantees that the Iris protocol provides.

We published 18 papers in journals and peer-reviewed conferences based on this work and we presented several invited talks, tutorials, and seminars to disseminate the results from this project. Notably, we organized the 2018 North American Summer school on Information Theory that was attended by approximately 80 graduate students including many from universities in the united states. The summer school presented an opportunity for graduate students to meet with and learn from senior researchers from academia and industry who presented tutorials. Three graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher were trained as experts in wireless communications, signal processing, information theory, control systems and cyber-physical systems.
